To the right honorable my singular good Lord
e L. Burghley Lord highe Treasurour of England.

16 feb
r
1590
. M
r
Bodeley to my L.

page.lettertext:
fol.184r
May it please yo
r
good L. for as muche
as S
r
John Norreis
is gone into
England,
wherof I was
advertised but three daies agoe, wheras his pro-
mise was to me, to remaine at
Middlebourgh,
or
Flushing,
for 8 or 10 daies, I am therfore to be-
seeche her
Ma
tie
most humbly, to send me some di-
rection, for my further proceeding w
t
e states of
these contreis. For
e people assuredly doe mur-
mur more and more, and they are earnestly
bent to stoppe
e passage of
e companies: whiche
they will not only endevo
r
, if
e souldiers passe
in troupes, but they have taken suche order, as they
can not come single. And although S
r
John Norreis
hath charged
e Captaines to casse
e companies,
and hath required
e Treasuro
rs
deputie to sur-
cease his paiment, after
e 20 day of this moneth,
supposing by that meanes, that
e townes must be
forced to permitte them to depart, yet undoub-
tedly
e contrey is so sharply sette against it, as
they will minister for a time, sufficient victualles
to
e souldiers, till they see there is no remedie,
but that her Hig
nes
will persist in her purpose in-
tended. In this troublesome case, the
C a ptaines are so doutfull, what course they should
folowe, as they write their letters every day to
knowe my advise. And for mine owne part, con-
sidering
e importance of
e mater,
e discontent-
ment of this people, and
e great inconvenience
of cassing
e companies, w
ch
most men hold opi-
nion, will scatter away by multitudes, considering
also that S
r
John Norreis hath bin in England this
sevenight, that her Hig
nes
both by him and otherwise
is effectually informed of
e state of these affaires,
fol.184v
and that
e winde hath bin good to bring us letters
from home, I have advised every captaine, to stay
the cassing of their bandes, till her Ma
ties
further
pleasure shall be notified unto them. The time,
I trust, will be but short, and a litle attendance
will be nothing prejudiciall to
e effecting of her
purpose. Rather I am persuaded, whensoever her
Hig
nes
shall resolve to drawe her subjectes from hens,
in suche sort as is begonne, this protracting of
e
time will serve in some sort to q
a
lifie these mens
choller, and to make
e action more easie, then it
would be otherwise. For I doe assure yo
r
L.
this dealing already of her Ma
tie
hath so muche
humbled and amased both
e
Count
and all
e
rest, that were wont to be so opposit to all her
proceedinges, as I doubt not for hereafter, but they
will shewe themselves more conformable.
The motion made by
e
Councel of state
to
e
Provinces, for
e newe levie of 3000 foote, and for
e renforcing of their horse bandes to 120 in every
bande, is generally accorded for 7 monethes: and
order shall be given, to perfourme it presently.
It is written from
Collen,
and also otherwise
confirmed, that
e Bishop of
Liege
, and
e
Duke
of Cleve
, have raised sundrie troupes of horse
and foote, w
t
full intention to chase away the
Spaniard from out of their territories. The
death of
La Mote
is advertised hither from sun-
drie places.
And thus I rest in expectation
of yo
r
L. next unto me, and take my humble
leave. From
e Hage. Fe
b
16 1590.
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley
